column2: Mean income (after tax)
column5:
Mean income.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column2: 7th decile (after tax)
column5:
The level of income below which 70% of the population falls.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.
column9: Greens
column10: multiplyBy avg_p80_dhi_eq 0.00274
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

column5:
The level of income per year below which 20% of the population falls.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.
column9: Purples
column10: multiplyBy thr_p20_dhi_eq 1
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column2: 7th decile (after tax)
column5:
The mean income per year within the 7th decile (tenth of the population).

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column2: Mean income (after tax)
column5:
Mean income.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income is per capita, which means that household income is divided by the total number of household members.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column2: Mean income (after tax)
column5:
Mean income per day.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income is per capita, which means that household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). column2: 3rd decile (after tax)
column5:
The mean income per month within the 3rd decile (tenth of the population).

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income is per capita, which means that household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income is per capita, which means that household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.
column9: Greens
column10: multiplyBy avg_p90_dhi_pc 1
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Mean income (before tax)
column5:
Mean income.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Poorest decile (before tax)
column5:
The level of income per month below which 10% of the population falls.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column2: 5th decile (before tax)
column5:
The mean income per month within the 5th decile (tenth of the population).

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column10: multiplyBy avg_p50_mi_eq 0.08333
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column10: multiplyBy thr_p60_mi_eq 1

column2: 7th decile (before tax)
column5:
The level of income per year below which 70% of the population falls.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column5:
Mean income.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income is per capita, which means that household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column2: Mean income (before tax)
column5:
Mean income per day.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income is per capita, which means that household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column10: multiplyBy avg_p10_mi_pc 0.00274
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income is per capita, which means that household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: 3rd decile (before tax)
column5:
The level of income per month below which 30% of the population falls.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income is per capita, which means that household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.

column5:

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Gini coefficients are obtained by using [Stata’s ineqdec0 function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366007.html). Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). From this function, mean and median values are also calculated.

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their [LISSY platform](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/data-access/lissy/). The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the [LIS PPP factor](https://www.lisdatacenter.org/resources/ppp-deflators/), available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Income shares and thresholds by decile are obtained by using [Stata’s sumdist function](https://ideas.repec.org/c/boc/bocode/s366005.html). The parameters set are again the weight (nhhmem*hwgt) and the number of quantile groups (10). Threshold ratios, share ratios and averages by decile are estimated after the use of LISSY with this data.
